I actually think that the lyric is 'Viral mess, turned dreams into an empire' - the idea that nowadays someone can post a video of them singing, or a piece of their art or fiction or whatever and turn their 'dream' into a massive career to make money- 'an empire' and then now the success that she (not necessarily Halsey but the generation of person that she's singing about) has found has allowed her to 'roll with the Rockerfellas'  - the most powerful, the richest people...

The song itself is definitely about this new generation of people who are growing up now who are becoming more liberal and accepting of social and economic differences ('Hamptons-bound but we don't feel like outsiders at all'), sexuality (second verse), diverse music tastes (?)('Raised on Biggie and Nirvana) etc etc. 

But I also feel like there's an air of sarcasm or maybe even a challenge in the song - if we finally do claim the fallen city and spread these 'new and improved' attitudes will we really be making a difference? Will we really be the New Americana or will we simply be a new generation of the idiots before us? ('What kind of bubblegum have you been blowing lately?') - what kind of dreams have you been exercising lately, your more interested in being a consumerist a follower of trends rather than a leader ( 'so we hold it down when summer starts' )- but can you hold down the city, these new ideologies once the summer ends? Can we BE the New Americana? 

Maybe I'm being too philosophical? Great political song, no wonder Halsey said that radios across America are 'terrified of playing it'.
comment_2:
"Rockefeller" always has connotations of blood money for me.

"The city's ours until the fall" brings Fight Club to mind.

"We know very well who we are, so we hold it down when summer starts" alludes IMO to how a lot of Americans deny how insecure they really are as leftists (read the unabomber manifesto). Also, how we thrive on coffee during the weekday, and beer on the weekend, and we're so hyped for friday and hungover on monday that we really only have three productive workdays a week.

"What kind of dough have you been spending/what kind of bubblegum have you been blowing lately?" seems to be saying that spending the dough is blowing your money, i.e. bubblegum is a waste of money, a lot of our consumerism is a waste of money.
I think hourly workers often forget that every eight dollars or so they spend is about an hour of gritting their way through work. I think they often forget to compare the quality of life lost by going to work with the effect their purchase has on their quality of life.

Regarding the confusing bit for ppl here that keeps getting IDed as metaphor or "don't know" - it just clicked in my head, so I may as well write it down.  First I am synopsisisising the video imagery though. So warning to TL:DR people - TL:DR alert :D


The video bits (which help explain the lyrics) 

The singer is singing from the position of a rogue group/colony leader, as Michael Hall posted -- she and her group are in no way "rich" with *money* - it seems in the video that no one is.  Even the soldiers are in minimal gear.   The rogue group are rich with freedom, knowledge, and in a self perceived *completely* different mindset than the generations before them.  (I'll explain, no h8 plzzz)

My impression is the âAmericanaâ is more than a snapshot of *now*, basically --this is a wider span than just Milennials, I'd say Gen X and younger â I was listening to Nirvana when I was 16/17.  Note in the minimovie production video of the ages of the people watching her be marched to the pyre.  They are attentive, but tired, with neutral faces, and one can guesstimate the age demographic of the people in the little village (which may be a metaphor for dystopian city) is like 35-55.  That feels like my generation to me (GenX).

Those older to slightly younger people looking overworked, tired, etc in their 30s/40s/50s, were just passively watching as she screamed, âHelp!  What are you doing?!  Why are you just standing there?!â.  Of course.  We're tired and old and jaded as anything,  Get off my lawn, dang kids.  Or maybe its just how a smaller fragment of our generation's subculture that was ânet connectedâ learned to handle things...  

The young faction steps out of the forest/jungle, ready to rescue their leader (who they silently ratted out when they got firing squad lined up â I cant lipread the vid on no sleep so I don't know what the soldiers were yelling at them to make them single her out)

...  However, when the smokebomb is tossed in, *all of them*, the passive watchers and the rogue faction, the âfollowersâ (as she is a leader, but didn't choose to be) leap to her rescue.  

There are things that are shared between some of  GenX and their children / neices/nephews / high school students / etc â internet and the ability to have unfettered free flowing communication with nothing but the content of our words effecting anyone's opinions of us â facelessly.   The internet, from baby usenet on old linux terminals in colleges and public libraries to now on every mobile phone ever, was a place where we could â and still can choose to - share solely our written word â no gender, no race, no age, no name â nothing to identify us save how we *choose to be identified*.  GenXers picked it up later than millenials, but âlaterâ was between the ages of as young as 15, to 25, starting with dial up BBSes (old cheesy 80's movie WarGames, anyone?).  We watched an age be born. Kinda cool.  But still get off my lawn.  

However, GenX who was online since there was an online tend to keep their heads down, or seem jaded and disinterested, because our upbringing was in some ways completely opposite.  We were latch-key kids â I was home by myself from 13 on for three to seven hours a day because my mother was a widow, and she worked to supplement a very small widow's pension.  And those of us with computers using computers were the nerds and the outcasts, after all â the literal 80s movie archetype of the glasses-taped skinny kid dropping his books in the hallway.  You learned to hide your heart in situations like that, back then no ones mom was going to rescue them from a bad day of bullying at school, there was no posting public to facebook and rallying a social justice response. If you got bullied, it was your fault for letting it effect you. Case in point:  Today there is a phrase âYou do not get to choose if your words hurt someone's feelingsâ.  But GenX, on the other hand, was raised with âNo one can make you feel inferior without your consent.â (Eleanor Roosevelt).  It's literally what we'd get told when we got home after getting jumped leaving schoolyard grounds.  And  the usual âtheyre just jealous of youâ âthey're afraid of you because you're smarter than themâ and the other usual bleh.

But here, in this sitation, things are going too far, even for those of us who sigh when we look fondly yet sadly at our old Doc Martens in the back of the closet.  They're are going to burn the leader alive, on a stake like a witch â archetypically defined as a woman with the powers to change reality, and therefore a threat to the âestablishmentâ. 

Subtle expression changes happen on the older watcher's faces, the one man clenches his jaw, the grey haired woman's eye expression changes slightly â and you see silouhettes in the smoke grenade cloud charge from ALL directions, not just where the leader's rogue group rescue party shows up. 3:37 â 3:48.  The âolder peopleâ who obviously can't afford a vacation in the Hamptons either (thanks housing bubble â thanks sooo much.  My credit rating was too high anyway) -- these people WILL help the young ones out when things get real, in any way they can â but they can not follow the rogue group as they flee to another location entirely.  They are just as burdened with debt (if not worse) as the young ones in their 20s because we're the ones who got lulled into thinking it was safe.  They have assets they can not leave behind, or will not leave behind.  Switching jobs is dangerous. Losing financial stability at a later age is horrific because the corporations literally pay less for younger, and so if a GenXer loses their job, losing their family home is a very possible reality.  There are too many ties that bind then down to where they are.  They can't escape to a pristine new place, either due to physical or mental reasons. Different mindset on some things â same mindset on others.

Lyric snippets here:


Vile romance, turned dreams into an empire 
(here I also hear âViral mess turned dreams into an Empireâ as moondustbaby did - think of everything that younger Gen X, then Y, Millenials, etc, have created that âgo viralâ - its a lot of things â a âmessâ.  Think of meme culture. Then realize there is a meme culture, which is simply people putting funny words on pictures of things that eventually aquiree inherent meaning even without words:  for example if I just put up a picture of Fry from Futurama looking âthoughtfulâ without any message written across it, the âsocial mediaâ generation will know the connection instantly and their head fills in ânot sure if [true thing] or [rediculously misinterpreted thing].  


Survival of the richest, the city's ours until the fall


They're Monaco and Hamptons-bound but we don't feel like outsiders at all

Split each line  in that couplet so you have a 4-line stanza:

Survival of the richest,  
(those who give the orders to the gun-wielders who capture the leader to burn her - and also a double entendre as to who is "rich" - and with what)
the city's ours until the fall ("ours" is the rebellious group living outside of the "organized" society in their own subculture - this is not the fall as in "falling" -- it is the fall as in Autumn, when the rich return from vacation.  "The city" is likely a metaphor for being out in the open in society - able to exist as "mainstream")

They're Monaco and Hamptons-bound 

(again, this line is about the rich giving the orders - they're the one's Monaco and Hamptons bound -- flying to the Hamptons and Monaco as they are common vacation spots in summer)

but we don't feel like outsiders at all 
(The "rebel" subculture does not feel disempowered that they have less than those in control, and that they can't do the same sort of things as the rich.  Their happiness / self worth is created as an internal.  They are comfortable in "the city" where they do as they please, again "until the fall")

We know very well who we are,  
(They are very aware that they are a new generation with views that are too radically misaligned with mainstream society)
so we hold it down when summer starts
(They hold down the city as one "holds down" a fortress  -- keeping possession of it .. again till autumn starts and vacation summer is over)
What kind of dough have you been spending?
(I hear "What kind of tool have you been tuned into in here?" (talking to the people casually watching the soldiers spilling gasoline all over her - âin hereâ might be in âthe cityâ)
What kind of bubblegum have you been blowing lately?
(Medicinal marijuana is distributed in chewing gum edible form. There *might* be a subtle reference here to the difference between those high on recreational versus government controlled distribution - state level or not. Dunno, but she's still talking to the people standing and staring, looking bored or simply neutral in the video who are not part of her rebel group.)
